review.title: Algebraic Properties of Qualitative Spatio-Temporal Calculi
review.abstract: Qualitative spatial and temporal reasoning is based on so-called qualitative calculi. Algebraic properties of these calculi have several implications on reasoning algorithms. But what exactly is a qualitative calculus? And to which extent do the qualitative calculi proposed meet these demands? The literature provides various answers to the first question but only few facts about the second. In this paper we identify the minimal requirements to binary spatio-temporal calculi and we discuss the relevance of the according axioms for representation and reasoning. We also analyze existing qualitative calculi and provide a classification involving different notions of a relation algebra.

metadata.title: Algebraic Properties of Qualitative Spatio-Temporal Calculi

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent decades, we have developed an enormous number of qualitative representations that relate to the representation of spatial and temporal domains based on finite sets of so-called qualitative relationships. Qualitative relationships serve to explicate knowledge relevant to a task while at the same time abstracting from irrelevant knowledge. Often, these relationships aim to relate to cognitive concepts. Qualitative spatial and temporal considerations link cognitive approaches to the representation of knowledge with formal methods. In mathematical terms, qualitative spatial and temporal argumentation is largely associated with satisfaction problems over infinite domains where qualitative relationships serve as constraints. Typical domains include points and intervals that are on the spatial side, regions or oriented points on the euclimatic level.

sections.heading: 2 Qualitative Representations
sections.text: In this section, we will formulate minimum requirements for qualitative calculations, discuss their relevance to spatio-temporal representation and reasoning, and list existing calculations. We will limit ourselves to calculations with binary relationships because we want to examine their algebraic properties using the notion of a relationship algebra that is best understood for binary relationships.

sections.heading: 2.1 Requirements to Qualitative Representations
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules they have set themselves.

sections.heading: 2.3 Existing Qualitative Spatio-Temporal Representations
sections.text: This paper deals with properties of binary spatio-temporal calculations, which are described in the literature and implemented in the spatial representation and thought tool SparQ [43, 42]. Table 1 lists these calculations.

sections.heading: 3 Relation Algebras
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Definition
sections.text: If we turn our attention to spatio-temporal calculations with binary relations, it is reasonable to ask whether they are relation algebras (RAs). If a calculation is an RA, it is guaranteed that it has properties that permit multiple optimizations with respect to constraints. sections.heading: 4 Algebraic Properties of Existing Calculi
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it will only be a matter of time before it will happen, until it does.

sections.heading: 5 A Quantitative Account of Qualitative Calculi
sections.text: In this section, we report on the arithmetical properties of specific calculations that go beyond the arithmetical complexity of constraint-based reasoning. (For example, one might know how many relationships are typically sufficient to describe a scene of n objects unambiguously or with a specific residual uncertainty.) To this end, we have developed two empirical measures that characterize certain aspects of qualitative calculations that are relevant for applications. (1) How well can calculations with many relationships make use of the normally higher information content? (2) Does the information content differ significantly between the six classes of calculations specified in Section 4? The first measurement we consider to be the information content of the composition operation is the estimation of how much additional information can be obtained by applying a composition operation. This allows us to estimate whether, for example, we have observed relationships r (A, B, C) and r (B) in a scene that is worth observing.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We looked at the spatio-temporal representation and reasoning from an algebraic perspective, examined the effects of algebraic properties on the modelling and reasoning of algorithms, and tested these properties on a representative corpus of existing calculations; the resulting classification shows that calculations described in the early literature tend to be located in the upper part of Figure 1; that is, they tend to have a rich algebraic structure. Few recently developed calculations are based on generalizations and have a weaker structure. We concluded that common reasoning methods for the latter class of calculations are wrong, and have proposed a corrected universal a-closure algorithm that applies reasoning optimizations where they are permitted. Furthermore, we found that algebraic properties are not necessarily related to how much information is preserved in successive reasoning steps. An interesting and significant line of future work by Jaicka is to support the extension of Jaicka's calculations to Andreae 401.

sections.heading: Rectangular Direction Relations

While DRAfp has been proven to be associative due to strong composition in [23], for OPRAm, it can be shown that none of the variants for any m are associative (see [28]).

As observed in [25], it is possible to equip them with a new id relation, modify the interpretation of the other relations such that they become JEPD, and adapt the converse and composition table accordingly.
, to use at least PC-2 [20].
An interesting and significant line of future work is to extend this study to ternary calculi, which requires an extension of binary relation algebras to ternary relations, see also [36].

metadata.abstractText: Qualitative spatial and temporal reasoning is based on socalled qualitative calculi. Algebraic properties of these calculi have several implications on reasoning algorithms. But what exactly is a qualitative calculus? And to which extent do the qualitative calculi proposed meet these demands? The literature provides various answers to the first question but only few facts about the second. In this paper we identify the minimal requirements to binary spatio-temporal calculi and we discuss the relevance of the according axioms for representation and reasoning. We also analyze existing qualitative calculi and provide a classification involving different notions of relation algebra.
